P2para.Text: Subsection (5ZA) is subject to section 219C in a case where the enforcer is a designated enforcer which is not a public body.

P1para.Text: After section 219 insert—

P2para.Text: In this Part, enhanced consumer measures are measures (not excluded by subsection (5)) falling within—

P3para.Text: the redress category described in subsection (2),
the compliance category described in subsection (3), or
the choice category described in subsection (4).

P2para.Text: The measures in the redress category are—

P3para.Text: measures offering compensation or other redress to consumers who have suffered loss as a result of the conduct which has given rise to the enforcement order or undertaking,
where the conduct referred to in paragraph (a) relates to a contract, measures offering such consumers the option to terminate (but not vary) that contract,

where such consumers cannot be identified, or cannot be identified without disproportionate cost to the subject of the enforcement order or undertaking, measures intended to be in the collective interests of consumers.

P2para.Text: The measures in the compliance category are measures intended to prevent or reduce the risk of the occurrence or repetition of the conduct to which the enforcement order or undertaking relates (including measures with that purpose which may have the effect of improving compliance with consumer law more generally).
The measures in the choice category are measures intended to enable consumers to choose more effectively between persons supplying or seeking to supply goods or services.
The following are not enhanced consumer measures—

P3para.Text: a publication requirement included in an enforcement order as described in section 217(8),
a publication requirement included in an undertaking accepted by the court as described in section 217(10), or
a publication requirement included in an undertaking accepted by a CPC enforcer as described in section 219(5A)(a).

P1group.Title: Inclusion of enhanced consumer measures etc.

P2para.Text: An enforcement order or undertaking may include only such enhanced consumer measures as the court or enforcer (as the case may be) considers to be just and reasonable.
For the purposes of subsection (1) the court or enforcer must in particular consider whether any proposed enhanced consumer measures are proportionate, taking into account—

P3para.Text: the likely benefit of the measures to consumers,
the costs likely to be incurred by the subject of the enforcement order or undertaking, and
the likely cost to consumers of obtaining the benefit of the measures.

P2para.Text: The costs referred to in subsection (2)(b) are—

P3para.Text: the cost of the measures, and
the reasonable administrative costs associated with taking the measures.

P2para.Text: An enforcement order or undertaking may include enhanced consumer measures in the redress category—

P3para.Text: only in a loss case, and

only if the court or enforcer (as the case may be) is satisfied that the cost of such measures to the subject of the enforcement order or undertaking is unlikely to be more than the sum of the losses suffered by consumers as a result of the conduct which has given rise to the enforcement order or undertaking.

P2para.Text: The cost referred to in subsection (4)(b) does not include the administrative costs associated with taking the measures.

Subsection (7) applies if an enforcement order or undertaking includes enhanced consumer measures offering compensation and a settlement agreement is entered into in connection with the payment of compensation.

A waiver of a person’s rights in the settlement agreement is not valid if it is a waiver of the right to bring civil proceedings in respect of conduct other than the conduct which has given rise to the enforcement order or undertaking.
The following definitions apply for the purposes of subsection (4)(a).
In the case of an enforcement order or undertaking under section 217, “a loss case” means a case in which—

P3para.Text: subsection (1) of that section applies (a finding that a person has engaged in conduct which constitutes an infringement), and
consumers have suffered loss as a result of that conduct.

P2para.Text: In the case of an undertaking under section 219, “a loss case” means a case in which—

P3para.Text: subsection (3)(a) or (b) of that section applies (a belief that a person has engaged or is engaging in conduct which constitutes an infringement), and
consumers have suffered loss as a result of that conduct.

P1group.Title: Availability of enhanced consumer measures to private enforcers

P2para.Text: An enforcement order made on the application of a designated enforcer which is not a public body may require a person to take enhanced consumer measures only if the following conditions are satisfied.

An undertaking given under section 217(9) following an application for an enforcement order made by a designated enforcer which is not a public body, or an undertaking given to such an enforcer under section 219, may include a further undertaking by a person to take enhanced consumer measures only if the following conditions are satisfied.
The first condition is that the enforcer is specified for the purposes of this section by order made by the Secretary of State.
The second condition is that the enhanced consumer measures do not directly benefit the enforcer or an associated undertaking.
Enhanced consumer measures which directly benefit a private designated enforcer or an associated undertaking include, in particular, measures which—

P3para.Text: require a person to pay money to the enforcer or associated undertaking,

require a person to participate in a scheme which is designed to recommend persons supplying or seeking to supply goods or services to consumers and which is administered by the the enforcer or associated undertaking, or
would give the enforcer or associated undertaking a commercial advantage over any of its competitors.

P2para.Text: The Secretary of State may make an order under subsection (3) specifying an enforcer only if the Secretary of State is satisfied that to do so is likely to—

P3para.Text: improve the availability to consumers of redress for infringements to which the enforcer’s designation relates,
improve the availability to consumers of information which enables them to choose more effectively between persons supplying or seeking to supply goods or services, or
improve compliance with consumer law.

P2para.Text: For section 47A substitute—

P1group.Title: Proceedings before the Tribunal: claims for damages etc.

P2para.Text: A person may make a claim to which this section applies in proceedings before the Tribunal, subject to the provisions of this Act and Tribunal rules.
This section applies to a claim of a kind specified in subsection (3) in respect of an infringement decision or an alleged infringement of—

P3para.Text: the Chapter I prohibition,
the Chapter II prohibition,
the prohibition in Article 101(1), or
the prohibition in Article 102.

P2para.Text: The claims are—

P3para.Text: a claim for damages;
any other claim for a sum of money;
in proceedings in England and Wales or Northern Ireland, a claim for an injunction.

P2para.Text: The right to make a claim in proceedings under this section does not affect the right to bring any other proceedings in respect of the claim.
In this Part (except in section 49C) “infringement decision” means—

P3para.Text: a decision of the CMA that the Chapter I prohibition, the Chapter II prohibition, the prohibition in Article 101(1) or the prohibition in Article 102 has been infringed,

a decision of the Tribunal on an appeal from a decision of the CMA that the Chapter I prohibition, the Chapter II prohibition, the prohibition in Article 101(1) or the prohibition in Article 102 has been infringed, or
a decision of the Commission that the prohibition in Article 101(1) or the prohibition in Article 102 has been infringed.

P2para.Text: Section 47A of the Competition Act 1998 (as substituted by sub-paragraph (1)) applies to claims arising before the commencement of this paragraph as it applies to claims arising after that time.
For section 47B substitute—
Subject to the provisions of this Act and Tribunal rules, proceedings may be brought before the Tribunal combining two or more claims to which section 47A applies (“collective proceedings”).
Collective proceedings must be commenced by a person who proposes to be the representative in those proceedings.
The following points apply in relation to claims in collective proceedings—

P3para.Text: it is not a requirement that all of the claims should be against all of the defendants to the proceedings,
the proceedings may combine claims which have been made in proceedings under section 47A and claims which have not, and
a claim which has been made in proceedings under section 47A may be continued in collective proceedings only with the consent of the person who made that claim.

P2para.Text: Collective proceedings may be continued only if the Tribunal makes a collective proceedings order.
The Tribunal may make a collective proceedings order only—

P3para.Text: if it considers that the person who brought the proceedings is a person who, if the order were made, the Tribunal could authorise to act as the representative in those proceedings in accordance with subsection (8), and
in respect of claims which are eligible for inclusion in collective proceedings.

P2para.Text: Claims are eligible for inclusion in collective proceedings only if the Tribunal considers that they raise the same, similar or related issues of fact or law and are suitable to be brought in collective proceedings.
A collective proceedings order must include the following matters—

P3para.Text: authorisation of the person who brought the proceedings to act as the representative in those proceedings,
description of a class of persons whose claims are eligible for inclusion in the proceedings, and
specification of the proceedings as opt-in collective proceedings or opt-out collective proceedings (see subsections (10) and (11)).

P2para.Text: The Tribunal may authorise a person to act as the representative in collective proceedings—

P3para.Text: whether or not that person is a person falling within the class of persons described in the collective proceedings order for those proceedings (a “class member”), but
only if the Tribunal considers that it is just and reasonable for that person to act as a representative in those proceedings.

P2para.Text: The Tribunal may vary or revoke a collective proceedings order at any time.

“Opt-in collective proceedings” are collective proceedings which are brought on behalf of each class member who opts in by notifying the representative, in a manner and by a time specified, that the claim should be included in the collective proceedings.
“Opt-out collective proceedings” are collective proceedings which are brought on behalf of each class member except—

P3para.Text: any class member who opts out by notifying the representative, in a manner and by a time specified, that the claim should not be included in the collective proceedings, and
any class member who—

P4para.Text: is not domiciled in the United Kingdom at a time specified, and
does not, in a manner and by a time specified, opt in by notifying the representative that the claim should be included in the collective proceedings.

P2para.Text: Where the Tribunal gives a judgment or makes an order in collective proceedings, the judgment or order is binding on all represented persons, except as otherwise specified.
The right to make a claim in collective proceedings does not affect the right to bring any other proceedings in respect of the claim.
In this section and in section 47C, “specified” means specified in a direction made by the Tribunal.
Section 47B of the Competition Act 1998 (as substituted by sub-paragraph (1)) applies to claims arising before the commencement of this paragraph as it applies to claims arising after that time.

P1para.Text: After section 47B (as substituted by paragraph 5) insert—

P2para.Text: The Tribunal may not award exemplary damages in collective proceedings.
The Tribunal may make an award of damages in collective proceedings without undertaking an assessment of the amount of damages recoverable in respect of the claim of each represented person.
Where the Tribunal makes an award of damages in opt-out collective proceedings, the Tribunal must make an order providing for the damages to be paid on behalf of the represented persons to—

P3para.Text: the representative, or
such person other than a represented person as the Tribunal thinks fit.

P2para.Text: Where the Tribunal makes an award of damages in opt-in collective proceedings, the Tribunal may make an order as described in subsection (3).

Where the Tribunal makes an award of damages in opt-out collective proceedings, any damages not claimed by the represented persons within a specified period must be paid to the charity for the time being prescribed by order made by the Lord Chancellor under section 194(8) of the Legal Services Act 2007.
The Secretary of State may by order amend subsection (5).

In this section—

P3para.Text: “damages” (except in the term “exemplary damages”) includes any sum of money which may be awarded by the Tribunal in collective proceedings (other than costs or expenses);

P1group.Title: Proceedings under section 47A or collective proceedings: injunctions etc.

P2para.Text: An injunction granted by the Tribunal in proceedings under section 47A or in collective proceedings—

P3para.Text: has the same effect as an injunction granted by the High Court, and
is enforceable as if it were an injunction granted by the High Court.

P2para.Text: In deciding whether to grant an injunction in proceedings under section 47A or in collective proceedings, the Tribunal must—

P3para.Text: in proceedings in England and Wales, apply the principles which the High Court would apply in deciding whether to grant an injunction under section 37(1) of the Senior Courts Act 1981, and
in proceedings in Northern Ireland, apply the principles that the High Court would apply in deciding whether to grant an injunction.

P1group.Title: Limitation or prescriptive periods for proceedings under section 47A and collective proceedings

P2para.Text: Subsection (2) applies in respect of a claim to which section 47A applies, for the purposes of determining the limitation or prescriptive period which would apply in respect of the claim if it were to be made in—

P3para.Text: proceedings under section 47A, or
collective proceedings at the commencement of those proceedings.

P2para.Text: Where this subsection applies—

P3para.Text: in the case of proceedings in England and Wales, the Limitation Act 1980 applies as if the claim were an action in a court of law;
in the case of proceedings in Scotland, the Prescription and Limitation (Scotland) Act 1973 applies as if the claim related to an obligation to which section 6 of that Act applies;
in the case of proceedings in Northern Ireland, the Limitation (Northern Ireland) Order 1989 applies as if the claim were an action in a court established by law.

P2para.Text: Where a claim is made in collective proceedings at the commencement of those proceedings (“the section 47B claim”), subsections (4) to (6) apply for the purpose of determining the limitation or prescriptive period which would apply in respect of the claim if it were subsequently to be made in proceedings under section 47A.
The running of the limitation or prescriptive period in respect of the claim is suspended from the date on which the collective proceedings are commenced.
Following suspension under subsection (4), the running of the limitation or prescriptive period in respect of the claim resumes on the date on which any of the following occurs—

P3para.Text: the Tribunal declines to make a collective proceedings order in respect of the collective proceedings;
the Tribunal makes a collective proceedings order in respect of the collective proceedings, but the order does not provide that the section 47B claim is eligible for inclusion in the proceedings;
the Tribunal rejects the section 47B claim;
in the case of opt-in collective proceedings, the period within which a person may choose to have the section 47B claim included in the proceedings expires without the person having done so;
in the case of opt-out collective proceedings—

P4para.Text: a person domiciled in the United Kingdom chooses (within the period in which such a choice may be made) to have the section 47B claim excluded from the collective proceedings, or
the period within which a person not domiciled in the United Kingdom may choose to have the section 47B claim included in the collective proceedings expires without the person having done so;

P3para.Text: the section 47B claim is withdrawn;
the Tribunal revokes the collective proceedings order in respect of the collective proceedings;
the Tribunal varies the collective proceedings order in such a way that the section 47B claim is no longer included in the collective proceedings;
the section 47B claim is settled with or without the Tribunal’s approval;
the section 47B claim is dismissed, discontinued or otherwise disposed of without an adjudication on the merits.

P2para.Text: Where the running of the limitation or prescriptive period in respect of the claim resumes under subsection (5) but the period would otherwise expire before the end of the period of six months beginning with the date of that resumption, the period is treated as expiring at the end of that six month period.

This section has effect subject to any provision in Tribunal rules which defers the date on which the limitation or prescriptive period begins in relation to claims in proceedings under section 47A or in collective proceedings.
Section 47E of the Competition Act 1998 does not apply in relation to claims arising before the commencement of this paragraph.

Pblock.Title: Settlements relating to infringements of competition law

P1group.Title: Collective settlements: where a collective proceedings order has been made

P2para.Text: The Tribunal may, in accordance with this section and Tribunal rules, make an order approving the settlement of claims in collective proceedings (a “collective settlement”) where—

P3para.Text: a collective proceedings order has been made in respect of the claims, and
the Tribunal has specified that the proceedings are opt-out collective proceedings.

P2para.Text: An application for approval of a proposed collective settlement must be made to the Tribunal by the representative and the defendant in the collective proceedings.
The representative and the defendant must provide agreed details of the claims to be settled by the proposed collective settlement and the proposed terms of that settlement.
Where there is more than one defendant in the collective proceedings, “defendant” in subsections (2) and (3) means such of the defendants as wish to be bound by the proposed collective settlement.
The Tribunal may make an order approving a proposed collective settlement only if satisfied that its terms are just and reasonable.
On the date on which the Tribunal approves a collective settlement—

P3para.Text: if the period within which persons may opt out of or (in the case of persons not domiciled in the United Kingdom) opt in to the collective proceedings has expired, subsections (8) and (10) apply so as to determine the persons bound by the settlement;
if that period has not yet expired, subsections (9) and (10) apply so as to determine the persons bound by the settlement.

P2para.Text: If the period within which persons may opt out of the collective proceedings expires on a different date from the period within which persons not domiciled in the United Kingdom may opt in to the collective proceedings, the references in subsection (6) to the expiry of a period are to the expiry of whichever of those periods expires later.
Where this subsection applies, a collective settlement approved by the Tribunal is binding on all persons falling within the class of persons described in the collective proceedings order who—

P3para.Text: were domiciled in the United Kingdom at the time specified for the purposes of determining domicile in relation to the collective proceedings (see section 47B(11)(b)(i)) and did not opt out of those proceedings, or
opted in to the collective proceedings.

P2para.Text: Where this subsection applies, a collective settlement approved by the Tribunal is binding on all persons falling within the class of persons described in the collective proceedings order.
But a collective settlement is not binding on a person who—

P3para.Text: opts out by notifying the representative, in a manner and by a time specified, that the claim should not be included in the collective settlement, or

is not domiciled in the United Kingdom at a time specified, and does not, in a manner and by a time specified, opt in by notifying the representative that the claim should be included in the collective settlement.

P2para.Text: This section does not affect a person’s right to offer to settle opt-in collective proceedings.
In this section and in section 49B, “specified” means specified in a direction made by the Tribunal.
Section 49A of the Competition Act 1998 applies to claims arising before the commencement of this paragraph as it applies to claims arising after that time.
After section 49A (inserted by paragraph 10) insert—

P1group.Title: Collective settlements: where a collective proceedings order has not been made

P2para.Text: The Tribunal may, in accordance with this section and Tribunal rules, make an order approving the settlement of claims (a “collective settlement”) where—

P3para.Text: a collective proceedings order has not been made in respect of the claims, but

if collective proceedings were brought, the claims could be made at the commencement of the proceedings (disregarding any limitation or prescriptive period applicable to a claim in collective proceedings).

P2para.Text: An application for approval of a proposed collective settlement must be made to the Tribunal by—

P3para.Text: a person who proposes to be the settlement representative in relation to the collective settlement, and

the person who, if collective proceedings were brought in respect of the claims, would be a defendant in those proceedings (or, where more than one person would be a defendant in those proceedings, such of those persons as wish to be bound by the proposed collective settlement).

P2para.Text: The persons applying to the Tribunal under subsection (2) must provide agreed details of the claims to be settled by the proposed collective settlement and the proposed terms of that settlement.
The Tribunal may make an order approving a proposed collective settlement (see subsection (8)) only if it first makes a collective settlement order.
The Tribunal may make a collective settlement order only—

P3para.Text: if it considers that the person described in subsection (2)(a) is a person who, if the order were made, the Tribunal could authorise to act as the settlement representative in relation to the collective settlement in accordance with subsection (7), and
in respect of claims which, if collective proceedings were brought, would be eligible for inclusion in the proceedings (see section 47B(6)).

P2para.Text: A collective settlement order must include the following matters—

P3para.Text: authorisation of the person described in subsection (2)(a) to act as the settlement representative in relation to the collective settlement, and
description of a class of persons whose claims fall within subsection (5)(b).

P2para.Text: The Tribunal may authorise a person to act as the settlement representative in relation to a collective settlement only if that person—

P3para.Text: is a person falling within the class of persons described in the collective settlement order for that settlement, or
is not such a person, but the Tribunal considers that it is just and reasonable for that person to act as the settlement representative in relation to that settlement.

P2para.Text: Where the Tribunal has made a collective settlement order, it may make an order approving a proposed collective settlement only if satisfied that its terms are just and reasonable.
A collective settlement approved by the Tribunal is binding on all persons falling within the class of persons described in the collective settlement order.
But a collective settlement is not binding on a person who—

P3para.Text: opts out by notifying the settlement representative, in a manner and by a time specified, that the claim should not be included in the collective settlement, or

is not domiciled in the United Kingdom at a time specified, and does not, in a manner and by a time specified, opt in by notifying the settlement representative that the claim should be included in the collective settlement.

P2para.Text: In this section, “settlement representative” means a person who is authorised by a collective settlement order to act in relation to a collective settlement.
Section 49B of the Competition Act 1998 applies to claims arising before the commencement of this paragraph as it applies to claims arising after that time.

P1para.Text: After section 49B (inserted by paragraph 11) insert—

P1group.Title: Approval of redress schemes by the CMA

P2para.Text: A person may apply to the CMA for approval of a redress scheme.
The CMA may consider an application before the infringement decision to which the redress scheme relates has been made, but may approve the scheme only—

P3para.Text: after that decision has been made, or
in the case of a decision of the CMA, at the same time as that decision is made.

P2para.Text: In deciding whether to approve a redress scheme, the CMA may take into account the amount or value of compensation offered under the scheme.
An approved scheme may not be varied by the CMA or the compensating party.
The Secretary of State may make regulations relating to the approval of redress schemes, and the regulations may in particular—

P3para.Text: make provision as to the procedure governing an application for approval of a redress scheme, including the information to be provided with the application;
provide that the CMA may approve a redress scheme only if it has been devised according to a process specified in the regulations;

provide that the CMA may approve a redress scheme only if it is in a form, or contains terms, specified in the regulations (which may include terms requiring a settlement agreement under the scheme to be in a form, or contain terms, specified in the regulations);
provide that the CMA may approve a redress scheme only if (so far as the CMA can judge from facts known to it) the scheme is intended to be administered in a manner specified in the regulations;
describe factors which the CMA may or must take into account, or may not take into account, in deciding whether to approve a redress scheme.

P2para.Text: The CMA must publish guidance with regard to—

P3para.Text: applications for approval of redress schemes,
the approval of redress schemes, and
the enforcement of approved schemes, and in particular as to the criteria which the CMA intends to adopt in deciding whether to bring proceedings under section 49E(4).

P2para.Text: Guidance under subsection (6) must be approved by the Secretary of State before it is published.
In this section and sections 49D and 49E—

Para.Text: “approved scheme” means a redress scheme approved by the CMA,
“compensating party” means a person offering compensation under an approved scheme,
“infringement decision” means—
a decision of the CMA that the Chapter I prohibition, the Chapter II prohibition, the prohibition in Article 101(1) or the prohibition in Article 102 has been infringed, or
a decision of the Commission that the prohibition in Article 101(1) or the prohibition in Article 102 has been infringed, and
“redress scheme” means a scheme under which a person offers compensation in consequence of an infringement decision made in respect of that person.

P2para.Text: For the purposes of this section and section 49E, “compensation”—

P3para.Text: may be monetary or non-monetary, and
may be offered to persons who have not suffered a loss as a result of the infringement decision to which the redress scheme relates.

P2para.Text: The CMA may require a person making an application for approval of a redress scheme to pay some or all of the CMA’s reasonable costs relating to the application.
A requirement to pay costs is imposed by giving that person written notice specifying—

P3para.Text: the amount to be paid,
how that amount has been calculated, and
by when that amount must be paid.

P2para.Text: A person required to pay costs under this section may appeal to the Tribunal against the amount.

Where costs required to be paid under this section relate to an approved scheme, the CMA may withdraw approval from that scheme if the costs have not been paid by the date specified in accordance with subsection (2)(c).
Costs required to be paid under this section are recoverable by the CMA as a debt.
A compensating party is under a duty to comply with the terms of an approved scheme (“the duty”).
The duty is owed to any person entitled to compensation under the terms of the approved scheme.

Where such a person suffers loss or damage as a result of a breach of the duty, the person may bring civil proceedings before the court for damages, an injunction or interdict or any other appropriate relief or remedy.

Where the CMA considers that the compensating party is in breach of the duty, the CMA may bring civil proceedings before the court for an injunction or interdict or any other appropriate relief or remedy.
Subsection (4) is without prejudice to any right that a person has to bring proceedings under subsection (3).
In any proceedings brought under subsection (3) or (4), it is a defence for the compensating party to show that it took all reasonable steps to comply with the duty.

Where the CMA considers that it is no longer appropriate for the compensating party to be subject to the duty, the CMA may give notice in writing to that party stating that it is released from the duty.

Where a person has entered into a settlement agreement with the compensating party, that agreement remains enforceable notwithstanding the release of the compensating party under subsection (7) from the duty.

P3para.Text: in England and Wales, the High Court or the county court,

P2para.Text: Where a person (“A”) fails to comply with an injunction granted by the Tribunal in proceedings under section 47A or 47B of the 1998 Act, the Tribunal may certify the matter to the High Court.
